abstract.text: Crucial roles of hematologic and immunologic responses in progression of COVID-19 74 remains largely unclear.

Objective: 76 We sought to address the dynamic changes of hematologic and immunologic 77 biomarkers and their associations with severity and outcomes of the disease. 78 Methods: 79 A retrospective study including 548 COVID-19 patients with clarified outcome 80 (discharged or deceased) from a national cohort in China was performed. 81 Cross-sectional and longitudinal variations were compared and the associations with 82 different severity and outcomes were analyzed.

83 Results: 84 On admission, the counts of lymphocytes, T cell subsets, eosinophils and platelets 85 decreased markedly, especially in severe/critical and fatal patients. Increased 86 neutrophil count and neutrophils-to-lymphocytes ratio were predominant in 87 severe/critical cases or non-survivors. During hospitalization, eosinophils, 88 lymphocytes and platelets were shown an increasing trend in survivors, but 89 maintained lower levels or dropped significantly afterwards in non-survivors.

90 Non-survivors kept high level or showed an upward trend for neutrophils, IL-6, 91 procalcitonin, D-dimer, amyloid A protein and C-reactive protein, which were kept 92 stable or shown downward trend in survivors. Positive correlation between CD8+ T 93 cell and lymphocytes count was found in survivors but not in non-survivors. A 94 multivariate Cox regression model suggested that restored levels of lymphocytes, 95 eosinophils and platelets could serve as the predictors for the recovery, while 96 progressive increases in neutrophils, basophils and IL-6 were associated with fatal 97 outcome. 98 Conclusions: 99 Hematologic and immunologic impairment showed a significantly different profile 100 between survivors and non-survivors in COVID-19 patients with different severity. 101 The longitudinal variations of these biomarkers could serve to predict recovery or 102 fatal outcome. 103 104 Abstract word count: 249 108 109 Clinical Implications: Restored lymphocytes, eosinophils and platelets could predict 110 recovery, while progressive increases in neutrophils and IL-6 were associated with 111 mortality. Altered interactions among immunologic and hematologic indices indicated 112 impaired immune responses in COVID-19.

113 114 Capsule summary: Hematologic and immunologic impairments were found in 115 COVID-19 patients, which was significantly obvious in severe/critical and fatal cases 116 than in mild/moderate individuals and survivors. The longitudinal variations may 117 serve as the predictors for clinical outcome.

MERS-CoV infection induced T cells' 158 apoptosis by a combination of extrinsic and intrinsic apoptosis pathways, which might 159 contribute to virus spread and the severe immunopathologic dysregulations 14 . 160 However, little is known about how different lymphocytes subsets and the kinetic 161 changes in immuno-related biomarkers differ during difference prognosis and 162 outcomes of COVID-19. More importantly, whether these changes can help to predict 163 the outcome of the disease remain largely unclear.

In this retrospective study, we aim to analyze clinical manifestations and outcomes, 165 hematologic, immunologic, lymphocytes subsets and infectious related bio-indices in 166 laboratory-confirmed cases based on a national cohort. With multivariate Cox 167 regression analysis, we attempt to investigate the potential risk factors associated with 168 the outcome of the disease.

FIGREF0.text: 144 respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) 2 . The disease has been named as 145 the Coronavirus Disease-2019 (COVID-19) by the World Health Organization.. Until 146 April 21, 2020, the outbreak of COVID-19 was reported in more than 2.3 million 147 confirmed cases globally 3 . Despite a reportedly lower fatality rate compared with the 148 10% of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) 4 and 37% of middle east 149 respiratory syndrome (MERS) 5 , COVID-19 has killed 4642 people in China and 150 158314 people outside China (by April 21, 2020) 3 . 151 Studies have revealed some changes in hematologic and immunologic indices in 152 patients with COVID-19 6-8 . The acute phase of the disease was found to be marked 153 lymphopenia, involving a dramatic loss of CD4+ T and CD8+ T cells 9,10 . Several 154 studies on SARS-CoV 11 , MERS-CoV 12 or SARS-CoV-2 13 infections have 155 investigated the correlation between abnormalities on laboratory indices including 156 leukocytes, lymphocytes and eosinophils counts, serum inflammatory cytokine levels Methods 170 Led by the China national health commission, a retrospective cohort to study the 171 laboratory confirmed COVID-19 admitted cases from 575 hospitals throughout China 172 was established 6 . The diagnosis of COVID-19 was made based on the World Health 173 Organization interim guidance 15 . By the time of March 22 nd , 2020, a total of 548 cases 174 with the clarified outcome (discharged or deceased) from the cohort were included, 175 patients with incomplete medical records or still in the hospitals were excluded. The 176 severity of the disease was assessed according to the Seventh Version of the Novel 177 Coronavirus Pneumonia Diagnosis and Treatment Guidance from national health 178 commission of China 16 . According to the severity, patients were categorized into 179 mild/moderate, severe or critical group upon admission. The study was approved by 180 national health commission and the ethics commission of the First Affiliated Hospital 181 of Guangzhou Medical University. The requirement for informed consent was waived 182 by the ethics commission due to the emerging infectious disease, records were copied and sent to the data processing center in Guangzhou, 187 under the coordination of the national health commission. A team of experienced 188 respiratory clinicians reviewed and abstracted the data. Data were entered into a 189 computerized database and cross-checked. The clinical data (including demographic 190 data, clinical symptoms and signs, comorbidities, laboratory findings, treatments 191 during hospitalization and clinical outcome) were extracted from electronic medical 192 records. Laboratory assessments consisted of complete blood counts, T cell subsets, 193 inflammatory indices, coagulation function, etc. The differences of the clinical 194 characteristics and laboratory findings in patients with different outcome or severity 195 would be addressed. Longitudinal tracing of the laboratory indices during the 196 hospitalization were performed. Furthermore, independent predicting factors 197 associated with the fatal outcome would also be investigated.

Three hematologic cells in pattern 1, including eosinophils, 278 lymphocytes and platelets, showed a significant continuous upward trend in survivors, 279 but a downward trend or keeping low in non-survivors (Figure 1A-C). On admission, 280 regardless of the severity or the outcome, majority of patients present an identical 281 eosinopenia. Level of lymphocytes was inversely proportional to disease severity, 282 with the highest in mild survivors and the lowest in critical survivors. During 283 hospitalization, survivors showed an increasing trend for both eosinophils (6-fold in 284 mid-term, and 8-fold at the end of hospitalization, p<0.001) and lymphocytes (1.2 -fold in mid-term, and 1.4-fold at the end of hospitalization, p<0.001), however, 286 non-survivors remained at low-level without a noteworthy increase. For platelets, 287 survivors showed a significantly higher level on admission and an increasing trend 288 during hospitalization (1.25-fold in mid-term and 1.24-fold at the end of 289 hospitalization, p<0.001) whereas non-survivors started with a low-level and dropped 290 significantly afterwards(1.07-fold and 2.13-fold, p<0.001). 291 Biomarkers in pattern 2 including leukocytes, neutrophils, NLR, IL-6, PCT, d-dimer, 292 PT, SAA, CRP and ferritin, were maintained at significant lower levels or showed a 293 slightly downward trend in survivors. During hospitalization, 298 survivors had comparable levels of IL-6 across three time points. Some novel findings were found as below. Firstly, not only the 353 lymphocytes and their subsets, but also the eosinophils decreased at the early stage, 354 associating with disease severity and clinical outcome. Altered immunologic 355 interactions among T cell subsets and hematologic indices in non-survivors indicated 356 impaired immune responses in COVID-19. Secondly, during the hospitalization, 357 dynamic changes of hematologic and immunologic indices varied in survivors and 358 non-survivors. Finally, multivariate Cox regression model suggested that restored 359 levels of lymphocytes, eosinophils and platelets could serve as the predictors of 360 recovery, while progressive increases in neutrophils, basophils and IL-6 were risk 361 factors for fatal outcomes of COVID-19. 362 Coronavirus infection (SARS and MERS) are confirmed to activate both innate 363 and adaptive immune responses. With the progression of the disease, uncontrolled 364 inflammatory responses may lead to subsequently local and systematic tissue injury. A 365 marked decrease in lymphocyte count has been reported associated with disease 366 severity of SARS and COVID-19 17-19 . We confirmed observations of a significantly 367 lower lymphocyte count and higher lymphopenia percentage on admission in 368 severe/critical COVID-19 patients than in mild/moderate ones. Furthermore, we 369 extend the observation by comparing lymphocyte levels between survivors and 370 non-survivors, showing that the initial levels of absolute lymphocyte count were 371 significantly lower and lymphopenia percentage significantly higher in non-survivors, regardless of the initial disease severity. Our data also revealed that the decreased 373 lymphocyte count was recovered to the normal level in survivors, while it was 374 sustained at low level in non-survivors, suggesting that restored lymphocyte numbers 375 are associated with the curative outcome of COVID-19.

FIGREF9.text: We further analyzed T lymphocyte subsets and confirmed the observation of 377 significant reduction of CD3+, CD4+ and CD8+ T cell subsets in severe/critical 378 patients than in mild/moderate ones 10, 20, 21 . Unfortunately, we couldn't obtain the379 kinetic changes of T cell subsets, since only samples on admission were performed 380 with flow cytometry in our patients. However, given the notification of marked 381 decreased initial counts of CD3+, CD4+ and CD8+ T cell subsets in non-survivors 382 than in survivors, we could speculate marked impairment of T lymphocytes is 383 associated with fatal outcome in COVID-19 patients. Decline of T lymphocytes via T 384 cell apoptosis in SARS and MERS patients is implicated to diminish the T cell 385 response, leading to further exuberant inflammatory responses 22,23 . Recent report by 386 Wang's group proved that SARS-CoV-2 could directly infect T cells through 387 receptor-dependent spike protein-mediated membrane fusion, despite a very low 388 expression level of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor in T cells 24 . 389 Further researches are needed to investigate whether SARS-CoV-2 infection could 390 induce T cells apoptosis. 391 In case of SARS, the CD4+/CD8+ ratio did not change significantly among 392 diverse severity or at different time points 11,25 . From current research, CD4+/CD8+ 393 ratio was found with no obvious difference among different severity, but with a 394 significant increase in non-survivors than in survivors. These findings indicate that 395 greater loss of CD8+ T cells might lead to fatal outcome in COVID-19 patients.

FIGREF10.text: CoV-specific T cells, especially CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, are crucial for virus 397 clearance and limiting further damage to host. Compared to CD4+ T cells which398 largely function via indirect mechanisms, virus specific CD8+ T cells directly target 399 infected cells 26 . Greater loss of CD8+ T cells might correlate to impaired virus 400 elimination in the early stage. Intriguingly, we found different correlations between CD8+ T cells and lymphocytes in non-survivors from survivors, indicating other 402 mechanisms underlying CD8+ T cells exhaustion might be involved. A pilot study 403 including 13 severe cases showed that the CD8+ T cells were functionally exhausted 404 in patients with COVID-19 through upregulation of an immune-checkpoint inhibitory 405 receptor, NKG2A. NKG2A + CD8+ T cells were found with increased percentage and 406 displayed a reduced ability to produce CD107a, IFN-γ, IL-2 and granzyme B. The 407 upregulated expression of NKG2A normalized in recovery subjects 27 . Aside from 408 reduction of cell numbers, functional exhaustion of CD8+ cells might contribute to 409 disease progression of COVID-19.

FIGREF11.text: In our study, most of the severe/critical and fatal patients demonstrated 411 eosinopenia, showing much lower level than mild/moderate and survival subjects on 412 admission. This result was consistent with those of other studies with acute infections 413 caused by SARS-CoV 28 MERS-CoV 12 and SARS-CoV-2 29,30 . The decline in 414 eosinophils might be owing to the response to stress of acute SARS-CoV-2 infection 31 . 415 Patients with severe respiratory syncytial virus infection had significantly higher 416 plasma cortisol levels and significantly lower eosinophil counts 32 . Other studies also 417 reported significantly decreased eosinophils in subjects with stress of heat 33 and force 418 swim 34 . However, whether SARS-CoV-2 has a direct effect on eosinophils remain 419 unknown. Recently, study found that the toxin of C. difficile transferase induces 420 pathogenic host inflammation via a Toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2)-dependent pathway, 421 resulting in the suppression of a protective host eosinophilic response 35 . In 422 experimental human endotoxemia, circulatory eosinopenia after an innate immune 423 challenge (intravenous challenge with endotoxin) is mediated by CD49d-mediated 424 homing of eosinophils to the tissues 36 . Similarly, with Liu's report 29 , we found 425 eosinophils continually increased and reached significantly higher levels in survivors 426 as compared with non-survivors, and a greater increase in eosinophils was associated 427 with better outcome in our Cox regression model. All the above findings suggest that 428 eosinophils might contribute to antiviral immunity in the lungs, and levels of 429 eosinophil counts at early stage and the kinetic changes may predict COVID-19 progression and recovery. 431 Our study indicated the platelets count as a clinical indicator of disease severity 432 and risk of mortality during hospitalization. Thrombocytopenia was identified as a 433 significant risk factor for disease severity and mortality in both SARS-CoV 37,38 and 434 MERS-CoV infected patients 39 . Furthermore, platelet count was selected in two 435 prognosis regression models by multivariate analysis 38,40 . A recent meta-analysis with 436 1779 COVID-19 patients revealed that the platelet count was significantly lower in 437 severe patients and even lower in non-survivors 41 . A hypothesis suggested that 438 damage to the lung tissue and pulmonary endothelial cells by virus infection would 439 result in 1) platelet activation, aggregation and entrapment, and further increasing the 440 consumption of platelets/megakaryocytes, and 2) reducing the production of platelets 441 in the lungs 37 . 442 Neutrophil dysfunction was previously reported as a distinct inflammatory 443 signature involved in the pathogenesis of SARS and MERS 22 . Severe outcomes, 444 including acute lung injury (ALI), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and 445 death, are associated with massive neutrophil infiltration in the lung and dramatically 446 elevated neutrophil counts in the peripheral blood 11, 42-44 . Higher neutrophil count on 447 admission was found in severe or critical than mild/moderate patients in our cohort, 448 consistent with previous reports 1,45 . Notably, kinetic analysis further revealed a 449 significant increase in initial neutrophil count, which persisted at higher levels at 450 end-hospitalization, was correlated with the fatal outcome. The NLR has been 451 reported as an independent predictor of disease severity in COVID-19 patients 45,46 .452We confirmed observation of higher initial NLR in severe/critical patients, and further 453 evaluated the potential of NLR as a prognostic factor. Compared to those in survivors 454 with low initial and a progressive declined NLR, significant higher NLR sustained 455 from on admission to end-hospitalization in non-survivors. Our results indicate that 456 NLR may serve as a potential factor for early identification of severity and to further 457 predicate outcomes in COVID-19.

FIGREF12.text: , then the virus activates innate immune system and adaptive immune462    system, resulting in the release of a large number of cytokines, including IL-6.463    Abnormality high levels of these cytokines/chemokine are considered to lead to tissue464 damage, accounting for respiratory failure or multiple organ failure. Among various 465 cytokines and chemokines (IL-2, IL-8, IL-17, GCSF, IP-10 and TNFα) identified, 466 IL-6 is one of the key cytokines with increased plasma level in both SARS and MERS, 467 as well as in COVID-19 21,47-49 . In accord with previous studies 20,21 , IL-6 was found 468 with a higher level on admission in non-survivors, as well as a marked increase 469 especially at the end of hospitalization compared to those in survivors. This indicates 470 that a sustained high level of IL-6 is related to a fatal outcome of SARS-CoV-2 471 infection. Interfering IL-6 by tocilizumab has been reported effectively improved 472 clinical symptoms and repressing the deterioration of severe and critical patients 50,51 .473Although not sufficient, our findings provide the further evidence that, in addition to 474 antiviral treatment of directly targeting or blocking viral entry, IL-6 may serve as a 475 potential therapeutic target for severe/critical COVID-19 patients.476Other conventional makers related to inflammatory damage, such as CRP, were 477 also significantly elevated in non-survivors at early stage and showed an upward trend 478 with progression, which is similar as reported in SARS 52 . Ferritin and SAA also 479 belong to acute phase proteins and can be used as prognostic markers for tissue injury480 or acute infections 53,54 . SAA was demonstrated a positive correlation with the extent 481 of pneumonia in SARS 55 . In the current study, consistent high levels of serum ferritin 482 and SAA were present in non-survivor during the hospitalization. Our study, with 483 another study on COVID-19 9 , found out a dynamic increasing of ferritin in 484 non-survivors since on admission. The longitudinal observation on these indexes 485 indicated the progressive immune-mediated damage in deceased patients. 486 From biomarker correlation networks, we found a significant 487 interaction among hematologic and immunologic cells in both survivors and non-survivors on admission, but with different patterns. It might indicate immunology 489 profile associated with host antiviral defense varied in different status. However, 490 comparing with subsiding of cell-to-cell interactions in survivors, strong correlations 491 sustained till end-hospitalization in non-survivors, suggested higher virus load plus 492 inflammatory turbulence might contributed to mortality of COVID-19. Currently, Cao 493 et al. reported that no benefit was observed with lopinavir-ritonavir treatment beyond 494 standard care in severe patients with COVID-19 56 . It is reasonable that combining 495 usage of anti-inflammatory and anti-viral medications may be more effective than 496 using either alone. Beside the tocilizumab, novel immune-mediated strategies (e.g. 497 mesenchymal stem cells), are under the trial to dampen inflammatory responses and 498 attenuate the inflammatory injury in COVID-19.499 Our study has several limitations. Firstly, due to the design of a retrospective study, 500 some indices were not detected in all patients. Lacking in the follow-up data of the T 501 cell subsets failed to perform a longitudinal analysis to unreal the recovery trends. 502 Secondly, except for the serum IL-6 and some clinical infection indexes, other 503 pro-inflammatory cytokines or chemokines associated with lymphocytes were not 504 detected. Further studies are necessary to characterize the role of T cell immune 505 response in COVID-19. Thirdly, data on the virus shedding or viremia profile are not 506 available, studies are further needed to describe the association between the virus 507 loading kinetics and the dynamic immune responses. study demonstrates hematologic and immunologic variations associated with 511 the severity and progression of COVID-19. Since the early stage of the disease, not 512 only the lymphocytes and T cell subsets, but also eosinophils present a marked 513 decrease, associating with the disease severity and clinical outcome. All p values were based on two-sided tests and were considered statistically significant at Demographics and baseline clinical characteristics229    A total of 548 patients with laboratory confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19 were included, with 345 patients categorized into mild/moderate, 155 severe and 48 critical degree on admission. The fatality rate was 60% in critical cases, followed by 34% in severe and 6% in mild/moderate patients (p<0.001). The mean age for all patients was 56 years with significantly older age for non-survivors than survivors (66.9 vs. 53.5, p<0.001). Among all non-survivors, 67% was male, reaching 83% in critical patients.Symptoms of cough, sputum and dyspnea were found significantly more common in severe or critical patients compared with mild/moderate counterparts (all p<0.05), and in non-survivors as compared with survivors (all p<0.05). Two hundred and forty-one 238 (44%) patients had at least one underlying comorbidity, of which 27% with hypertension, 11% with diabetes, 3% with cerebrovascular disease, which was significantly higher in non-survivors than survivors (all p<0.001). Only 2 (0.4%) patients reported having asthma and 18 (3%) reported other allergic diseases mostlyInitial laboratory findings among hospitalized patients with different outcomeOn admission, the hematologic profile varied among patients with different outcome and severity(Table 2). Compared with the survivors, eosinopenia, lymphopenia, and decreased platelets were much common in non-survivors (all p<0.05), which accounted for 80.5%, 96.6% and 34.5%, respectively. The trend of the gradual decreasing of eosinophils and lymphocytes among patients with varying degree of severity was identical. Oppositely, non-survivors showed significantly elevated level of leukocytes, neutrophils, the neutrophils-to-lymphocytes ratio (NLR) and the platelets-to-lymphocytes ratio (PLR) (all p<0.05). Moreover, compared with mild/moderate, severe and critical patients showed a higher incidence of abnormal leukocytes, neutrophils, NLR and PLR.T cell subsets were further analyzed in 141 patients on admission (demography showed in supplementalTable E1). In patients with different outcomes, non-survivors showed significant decrease in total number of CD3+ T cells, CD4+ T and CD8+ T cells in peripheral blood, compared with survivors (all p<0.001).
